newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Canberra officials push for welfare cut - paper.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Canberra officials push for welfare cut - paper.

text.p: Australian civil servants will advise the national government to further slash welfare funding in its next budget, for 1997/98 (July/June), by targeting pensions and housing assistance, a newspaper said on Sunday.

The powerful treasury and finance ministries would suggest the government change the way pensions were indexed when its expenditure review committee, dubbed the "razor gang", meets next month, The Sunday Age said in an unsourced report.
The finance ministry would also push for the committee to cut national and restructure housing assistance to save around A$500 million, the report said.

The conservative government attempted in the 1996/97 budget announced in August to put in place measures aimed at reducing the budget by a total A$7.2 billion by the end of 1997/98, but the Senate or upper House trimmed this by A$300 million to A$400 million.
The Sunday Age quoted Finance Minister John Fahey as refusing to comment on the proposed changes for 1997/98, calling them mere speculation.
The government has previously rejected suggestions that pensions be indexed in such a way as to slash its welfare bill.
The next budget is to be announced on May 13.
